You are correct that the Industrial Revolution had both winners and losers. Some countries were able to take advantage of the new technologies and industrial processes to become economic powerhouses, while others struggled to keep up.

Here are some of the countries that benefited the most from the Industrial Revolution:

1. Britain: Britain was the birthplace of the Industrial Revolution, and it quickly became the world's leading industrial and economic power. Britain's factories and mines produced goods that were cheaper and more plentiful than ever before, and the country's traders and merchants dominated global markets.

2. United States: The United States was another major beneficiary of the Industrial Revolution. Its vast natural resources, including coal, iron, and timber, provided the raw materials needed for industrial production. The US also had a large and growing domestic market, which fueled economic growth and development.

3. Germany: Germany was a relatively latecomer to the Industrial Revolution, but it quickly caught up and soon became one of the world's leading industrial powers. Germany's strong manufacturing base and well-developed infrastructure helped it to build a powerful and dynamic economy.

4. Japan: Japan was also a latecomer to industrialization, but it was able to leverage its strong government and centralized economy to rapidly catch up with the rest of the world. Japan's focus on high-quality manufacturing and advanced technology helped it to establish itself as a major economic power.

5. France: France was already a major economic and cultural power before the Industrial Revolution, but the new technologies and processes helped it to maintain its position. French factories produced luxury goods that were in high demand around the world, and French merchants and traders were active in global markets.

These are just a few of the countries that benefited from the Industrial Revolution. Of course, the benefits were not evenly distributed, and many other countries struggled to keep up with the pace of change.
